title: Consumer Protection Laws regarding purchased items and permanent suspensions.
body:
I have recently found out that what I have purchased from Riot is rented, not purchased. This is a secret which is only revealed after the fact. 
I have been suspended two times and if it happens again it will likely be a permanent suspension. 
The problem with this is that the items I paid for with real money in a business transaction are actually for sale, because I bought them and I am protected under consumer protection laws. 
Ban or not, if I pay for something and it is taken away, then my money should be taken back and given to me for the things I paid for. 
I do not trust Riot at this point because they banned be for vary vague reasons and claim their summoners code states that being toxic or mean can get you a suspension in the hopes of reforming my behavior. 
Okay here is a simple solution, CHAT BAN. 
The game should be trying to get as many players as possible, not kick people out who get voted to be banned because they said something or made a mistake. I didn't break any real rules in this last ban, I just wasn't being very nice and neither was my team, so why am I the person who gets the ban? (Don't answer that I don't care) 
Riot is not your parents, they can't insist on reforming your behavior, and the fact that behavior is an issue is due to the internet sucking real bad and the fact the client supports chat. 
They need to fix the problem and stop banning people and making enemies. 
I assure you if enough people who paid hundreds of dollars for RP and skins start getting banned, there will be a huge lawsuit for unfair trade practices.

Sounds like you have yet to read the [ToU](http://oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/legal/termsofuse) and [EULA](http://oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/legal/eula), which you *must* have agreed to before actually playing (this happens on account creation, with *every* patch and every time the "agreements" are updated).  It is stated in ***both*** that the Account and "Virtual Items" are owned by Riot (section IV "Ownership" of the EULA and section 4 "Virtual Items" of the ToU [the TOU is a lot more thorough about the specifics]).

TLDR Riot isn't hiding anything, you've just failed to read the agreements you've told Riot you *read, understood and are fully willing to accept*. From what I understand, there is no breach of consumer law here.

First of all, as you say, you rent the content from Riot. You legally acknowledge this every time you click yes to the EULA and ToS so ignorance of the fact won't help your legal defence any. If you leave or get kicked out of a rental home, you don't get the rent back now do you?

Second, even if you did own the content, there is an exception in the ACL regarding "Life of Purchase" and returns. My getting your account banned you would effectively be ending the life of purchase (same as if you say, dropped a laptop on the ground then jumped on it a bunch of times) and you would still have no good legal defence. 

Third, you don't get banned for no reason. A false positive may happen every once and a while, but for one person twice? Sorry but no. If you really think it was a false ban then post your chat logs and prove it and maybe something can be done about it.

Fourth, the vast majority of players would see a chat restriction and go "oh shit, I need to fix this, if only so I don't get banned and lose all my shit", whereas your attitude seems to be "I was an asshole ruining a whole buncha people's games and I got banned for it? Nah screw that I'm gonna sue Riot to preserve my right to be an asshat". For some players, the only deterrent to negative behaviour is the idea of permanent monetary loss, for some others, even that is not enough and they get banned.

This is a free to play game. Easy to join and easier to leave. The biggest deterrent to new players isn't how much money they have to spend to play it (WoW) or the lack of quality content (most other ftp MMOs) or anything like that it's the toxicity. If you're first game as a new player is someone abusing you, insulting your race and threatening to do things to your mother, you aren't really going to be inclined to stick around are you?

If you really think you can sue them though, you're welcome to take it up with their legal team. Good luck to you. OR, hear me out here, you could just stop being toxic in game. Yell at your screen, write angry letters, find some other outlet.

Any legal terms of use or anything written about the summoners code doesn't excuse them from business laws just because its on the internet, its a game, or they feel they can make up their own laws. Terms of use are not laws that govern fair trade agreements. Imagine if you were to rent a house for a month, and in the terms of agreement it specified if you are too loud, then you can be banned from using the house. Well you pay the rent for that month, and the landlord tells you that you were too loud when you paid, and bans you from the house for 2 weeks. Hey, you don't own the house, and you broke the terms of use agreement by being too loud. This is illegal no matter what the terms of use are because state and federal laws dictate what you can and can't do in tenant situation to protect people from being abused or taken advantage of. 
Business laws and consumer protection laws work the same way on the state and federal levels, it protects people from exploitable situations when making business transactions, which in this case is clearly exploitable. 

First the rules are not clear, meaning there is not an actual standard for being banned, its based on how others feel you have acted and its automated, so its not based on any standard. 
Also they don't tell you the things you pay for are rented, plus give you no way of getting your money back if they decide to ban you. 
Lastly the perma ban doesn't keep players from playing the game, it just takes access to the account with the money spent on it, which doesn't ban people from the game, it just steals their money and makes them have to pay for all the stuff again on another account if they want it back, which is exploitable. 
Why ban people if it doesn't work anyway, and why steal people's money? This is not legal or right no matter what they say in the ToU because they can't write their own laws, no one voted on these terms and on how to ban people, and its a unfair without and real clear standard.

Let's be clear here, there are literally thousands of game companies that use agreements that are basically the same as what Riot have set out, if this kind of thing was illegal you can bet that there would be at least *one* case where someone had successfully won in this kind of situation, and if that had happened you can bet all the other companies would have taken notice and changed their agreements.

I would also like to say that your analogy isn't too great for the point you're trying to make. There are laws regarding "noise pollution", so if there were something in the rental agreement about the landlord reserving to right to revoke your access to the property should you be "too noisy", and they had received complaints from neighbours about the noise, then (based on what I understand) they *would* have the right to exercise that part of the rental agreement.

Things aren't necessarily as black and white as you seem to think they are, there's a lot of nuances involved in these kinds of legal situations that make it basically wrong to say that a situation is always one way in the eyes of the law.

> Also they don't tell you the things you pay for are rented, plus give you no way of getting your money back if they decide to ban you.

As I pointed out before, Riot do indeed inform players that all accounts and "virtual items" are indeed owned by Riot and "rented out". If you were to go to court over something like this, it would certainly come up about the agreements and whether you had accepted them. If you were to answer "yes", they would point out that it is all explained in the ToU and, thus, you *must* have been well aware of the terms of purchasing RP. If you were to answer "no", they would point out that you have no legal position to take responsibility for the account, and therefor have no case.

Quite simply, ignorance isn't a defence.

> First the rules are not clear, meaning there is not an actual standard for being banned, its based on how others feel you have acted and its automated, so its not based on any standard.

There have been plenty of discussions involving Rioters about what is and isn't acceptable behaviour. There are plenty of ways for players to find out what will likely result in a punishment. The baseline of it is "don't be a jerk", which should be pretty simply to accomplish considering it takes no effort whatsoever to *not* do something.

As a final note, if a player get's perma-banned, then chooses to make a new account and purchase RP, that's not Riot exploiting the player. That's the player making the conscious decision to spend money on a game where they've been previously banned. Riot isn't responsible for the actions of the players, and don't try to argue that they are because that won't go down in court at all.

Business and Professions Code - BPC
DIVISION 7. GENERAL BUSINESS REGULATIONS [16000 - 18001]  ( Division 7 added by Stats. 1941, Ch. 61. )
PART 3. REPRESENTATIONS TO THE PUBLIC [17500 - 17930]  ( Part 3 added by Stats. 1941, Ch. 63. )
CHAPTER 1. Advertising [17500 - 17606]  ( Chapter 1 added by Stats. 1941, Ch. 63. )

ARTICLE 1. False Advertising in General [17500 - 17509]  ( Article 1 added by Stats. 1941, Ch. 63. )

17500.
  

It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association, or any employee thereof with intent directly or indirectly to dispose of real or personal property or to perform services, professional or otherwise, or anything of any nature whatsoever or to induce the public to enter into any obligation relating thereto, to make or disseminate or cause to be made or disseminated before the public in this state, or to make or disseminate or cause to be made or disseminated from this state before the public in any state, in any newspaper or other publication, or any advertising device, or by public outcry or proclamation, or in any other manner or means whatever, including over the Internet, any statement, concerning that real or personal property or those services, professional or otherwise, or concerning any circumstance or matter of fact connected with the proposed performance or disposition thereof, which is untrue or misleading, and which is known, or which by the exercise of reasonable care should be known, to be untrue or misleading, or for any person, firm, or corporation to so make or disseminate or cause to be so made or disseminated any such statement as part of a plan or scheme with the intent not to sell that personal property or those services, professional or otherwise, so advertised at the price stated therein, or as so advertised. Any violation of the provisions of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment in the county jail not exceeding six months, or by a fine not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500), or by both that imprisonment and fine.

(Amended by Stats. 1998, Ch. 599, Sec. 2.5. Effective January 1, 1999.)
